Instructions -or ritz dycrattxnia ~cn;nata
The cnidarian Hydractinia is frequently found on the shells of small hermit
crabs. This animal exists as a colony which is composed of three kinds of individuals:
1) feeding polyps, 2) stinging polyps and 3) reproductive polyps. The sexes are
separate in Hvdractinia; some colonies are male while others are female. Ripe
females can be distinguished because the reproductive individuals have gonophores
with large opaque eggs while the males have 
Gametes are obtained from these animals by spawnings. The timing of spawning
is controlled by the light cycle. Normally the animals are maintained in a lab with
the light on at all times. Animals are prepared for spawning by putting them in the
dark for 3-A hours. Spawning takes place about one hour after subsequent re-exposure
to light. Generally the males and females are maintained in separate bowls and the
eggs are fertilized at will by adding or 2 drops of seawater from a male bowl to a
culture of eggs. In oocytes the germinal vesicle breaks down soon after exposure to
light, the meiotic reduction divisions occur just before spawning.
Spawned eggs are covered with a jelly coat which swells on exposure to sea water.
Fertilization of these eggs takes place at the site of polar body formation. The
egg produces a chemoatractant which causes the sperm to swim toward it. The first
cleavage begins about one hour after fertilization. Cleavage is unipolar. Over the
next two days this embryo will transform into a ciliated non-feeding planula larva.
This larvae is radially sylnetrical. It has an ectodermal and an endodermal cell
layer. There are several cell tgnes in both tissue layers. After a larval period which
can be as short as two days the larvae settles and undergoes metamorphosis. During
the process of metamorphosis the larvae attaches at its anterior end and its posterior
end transforms into the hydranth of the polyp.

Laboratory directionsj 4

l) Watch the process of sperm chemotaxis and fertilization:
Coat a siliclad treated slide with albumin. The albumin prevents the sperm from
sticking to the slide and allows the sea water to form a large flat drop. Place or
2 eggs in the drop, Find the eggs using your 10x objective (use dark feild illumination
or stop your condensor down). Add sperm some distance from the eg; so that their
aeproach to the egg and subsequent behavior can be observed. (Note: you oi ht rant
to an unfertilized een in dal? so that one half has the site of polar body formation
and one half does not, and examine sperm behavior around each half.)
Z)Mark parts of the early embryo so that the presumptive fate of different regions
can be traced:
Early embryos can be marked with a 1% solution of the dye nile blue which has
been imobilized in agar in a micropipette. Nile blue A is made up as a 1% solution
in distilled water. Agar is added and the solution is heated to dissolve the aiar.
Enough agar is used anywhere between 2 and a lOl solution) so that when the solution
cools gel will form. A short piece of capillary tueinj is partly filled by im# rein"
one end in a hot solution of agar. When tke agar has cooled, the part of the :nba
which has no aiar is heated with a microflame and pulled out to the desired hors. Tb?
other and of the tube is then sealed off and the fieroflahe applied to the part o'
